message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Environmental stress destabilizes microbial networks
Paper Abstract: Abstract Environmental stress is increasing worldwide, yet we lack a clear picture of how stress disrupts the stability of microbial communities and the ecosystem services they provide. Here, we present the first evidence that naturally-occurring microbiomes display network properties characteristic of unstable communities when under persistent stress. By assessing changes in diversity and structure of soil microbiomes along 40 replicate stress gradients (elevation/water availability gradients) in the Florida scrub ecosystem, we show that: (1) prokaryotic and fungal diversity decline in high stress, and (2) two network properties of stable microbial communities—modularity and negative:positive cohesion—have a clear negative relationship with environmental stress, explaining 51–78% of their variation. Interestingly, pathogenic taxa/functional guilds decreased in relative abundance along the stress gradient, while oligotrophs and mutualists increased, suggesting that the shift in negative:positive cohesion could result from decreasing negative:positive biotic interactions consistent with the predictions of the Stress Gradient Hypothesis. Given the crucial role microbiomes play in ecosystem functions, our results suggest that, by limiting the compartmentalization of microbial associations and creating communities dominated by positive associations, increasing stress in the Anthropocene could destabilize microbiomes and undermine their ecosystem services.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Payment for ecosystem services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Payment_for_ecosystem_services"},{"title":"Ecosystem service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_services"},{"title":"Ecological goods and services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_goods_and_services"},{"title":"Talk:Ecosystem service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Ecosystem_services"},{"title":"Millennium Ecosystem Assessment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millennium_Ecosystem_Assessment"},{"title":"Ecosystem valuation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_valuation"},{"title":"Boreal ecosystem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boreal_ecosystem"},{"title":"The Economics of Ecosystems and Biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Economics_of_Ecosystems_and_Biodiversity"},{"title":"Nature-based solutions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nature-based_solutions"},{"title":"Kruti - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kruti"}]

## Ecosystem Services

Ecosystem services, or eco-services, are the goods and services provided by ecosystems to humans, defined by the 2006 Millennium Ecosystem Assessment as "the benefits people obtain from ecosystems".

### Categories of Ecosystem Services

The Millennium Ecosystem Assessment groups these services into four categories: regulating services, provisioning services, cultural services, and supporting services, where supporting services are regarded as the basis for the services of the other three categories.

The broad categories include food production (crops, livestock, capture fisheries, aquaculture, and wild foods), fiber (timber, cotton, hemp, and silk), genetic resources (biochemicals, natural medicines, and pharmaceuticals), fresh water, air quality regulation, climate regulation, water regulation, erosion regulation, water purification and waste treatment, disease regulation, pest regulation, pollination, natural hazard regulation, and cultural services.

### Economic Valuation

In 2014, ecosystem services were valued at $125–145 trillion annually, demonstrating the enormous economic importance of natural systems.

### Key Examples

Different ecosystems provide different services. For instance, estuarine and coastal ecosystems provide provisioning services including marine and genetic resources, supporting services such as nutrient cycling and primary production, regulating services including carbon sequestration and flood control, and cultural services including recreation and tourism.

The Millennium Ecosystem Assessment popularized the term ecosystem services, highlighting their critical role in human well-being and environmental sustainability.

Here are the search results for "mutualism biology":

## Definition

Mutualism describes the ecological interaction between two or more species where each species has a net benefit.(no content)Mutualism is a common type of ecological interaction.

## Key Examples

Prominent examples include the nutrient exchange between vascular plants and mycorrhizal fungi, where the plant provides carbohydrates to the fungus in return for primarily phosphate and nitrogenous compounds, as well as rhizobia bacteria that fix nitrogen for leguminous plants in return for energy-containing carbohydrates.(no content)A prominent example of pollination mutualism is with bees and flowering plants, where bees use these plants as their food source with pollen and nectar, and in turn, they transfer pollen to other nearby flowers, allowing for cross-pollination.

## Evolutionary Significance

Mutualism is thought to have driven the evolution of much of the biological diversity we see, such as flower forms and co-evolution between groups of species.(no content)Mutualism has also been linked to major evolutionary events, such as the evolution of the eukaryotic cell and the colonization of land by plants.

## Classification

It is common to categorise mutualisms according to the closeness of the association, using terms such as obligate and facultative.

Web search results for query: "pathogenic microorganisms"

Links: [{"title":"Pathogenic bacteria - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathogenic_bacteria"},{"title":"Category:Pathogenic microbes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Pathogenic_microbes"},{"title":"Pathogenic microorganisms in frozen environments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathogenic_microorganisms_in_frozen_environments"},{"title":"Pathogen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathogen"},{"title":"Bacteria - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacteria"},{"title":"Category:Pathogenic bacteria - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Pathogenic_bacteria"},{"title":"Food spoilage - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_spoilage"},{"title":"Microbiology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbiology"},{"title":"Human pathogen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_pathogen"},{"title":"Exogenous bacteria - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exogenous_bacteria"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of pathogenic microorganisms:

## Definition and Types

Pathogenic microorganisms typically include viruses, bacteria, protozoa, prions, viroids, and fungi. A pathogen is any organism or agent that can produce disease.

## Key Characteristics

Pathogenic bacteria are specially adapted with mechanisms for overcoming normal body defenses and can invade parts of the body, such as the blood, where bacteria are not normally found. Infection usually occurs only if the body's defense mechanisms are damaged by some local trauma or an underlying debilitating disease.

## Major Pathogens by Type

**Bacteria:** Pathogenic bacteria cause diseases such as pneumonia (caused by Staphylococcus, Streptococcus and Pseudomonas) and foodborne illnesses (caused by bacteria such as Shigella, Campylobacter, and Salmonella).

**Viruses:** Notable pathogenic viruses cause smallpox, influenza, mumps, measles, chickenpox, ebola, and rubella.

**Protozoans:** Many protozoans act as pathogenic parasites causing diseases like malaria, amoebiasis, giardiasis, toxoplasmosis, cryptosporidiosis, trichomoniasis, Chagas disease, leishmaniasis, African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), Acanthamoeba keratitis, and primary amoebic meningoencephalitis.

## Global Health Impact

A GBD study estimated that bacterial pathogen infections contributed to approximately one in 8 deaths (or ~7.7 million deaths) globally in 2019.

Here are the search results for "network theory":

## Overview

In mathematics, computer science, and network science, network theory is a part of graph theory.(no content)It defines networks as graphs where the vertices or edges possess attributes.(no content)Network theory analyses these networks over the symmetric relations or asymmetric relations between their (discrete) components.

## Applications

Network theory has applications in many disciplines, including statistical physics, particle physics, computer science, electrical engineering, biology, archaeology, linguistics, economics, finance, operations research, climatology, ecology, public health, sociology, psychology, and neuroscience.(no content)Applications of network theory include logistical networks, the World Wide Web, Internet, gene regulatory networks, metabolic networks, social networks, epistemological networks, etc.

## Key Areas

Some specific applications include:

- **Social Networks**: Social network analysis examines the structure of relationships between social entities. These entities are often persons, but may also be groups, organizations, nation states, web sites, or scholarly publications.

- **Biological Networks**: With the recent explosion of publicly available high throughput biological data, the analysis of molecular networks has gained significant interest.

- **Risk Assessment**: Network theory tools can be applied across various systems to analyze relationships and patterns within complex systems.

## Historical Context

Euler's solution of the Seven Bridges of Königsberg problem is considered to be the first true proof in the theory of networks.

Links: [{"title":"Soil microbiology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil_microbiology"},{"title":"Root microbiome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Root_microbiome"},{"title":"Rhizosphere - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhizosphere"},{"title":"Agricultural microbiology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agricultural_microbiology"},{"title":"Microorganism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microorganism"},{"title":"Soil health - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil_health"},{"title":"Soil regeneration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil_regeneration"},{"title":"UK Crop Microbiome Cryobank - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UK_Crop_Microbiome_Cryobank"},{"title":"Regenerative agriculture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regenerative_agriculture"},{"title":"Bioremediation of oil spills - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bioremediation_of_oil_spills"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the soil microbiome:

## Overview

Soil microbiology is the study of microorganisms in soil, their functions, and how they affect soil properties.(no content)Soil microorganisms can be classified as bacteria, actinomycetes, fungi, algae and protozoa.

## Composition and Abundance

Up to 10 billion bacterial cells inhabit each gram of soil in and around plant roots, a region known as the rhizosphere.(no content)Bacteria and Archaea, the smallest organisms in soil apart from viruses, are prokaryotic and are the most abundant microorganisms in the soil, serving many important purposes, including nitrogen fixation.

## Key Functions

Microbes can make nutrients and minerals in the soil available to plants, produce hormones that spur growth, stimulate the plant immune system and trigger or dampen stress responses. More specifically, the soil microbiome plays an essential role in nutrient cycling by decomposing organic matter and releasing essential nutrients for plant growth.

## Benefits of Diversity

In general a more diverse soil microbiome results in fewer plant diseases and higher yield. Additionally, soil microbial diversity is critical for maintaining fertility and resilience against the changing climate, and regenerative practices have been shown to enhance and support this biodiversity.

Web search results for query: "ecological stability"

Links: [{"title":"Ecological stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_stability"},{"title":"Ecological effects of biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_effects_of_biodiversity"},{"title":"Resistance (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resistance_(ecology)"},{"title":"Carboniferous rainforest collapse - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carboniferous_rainforest_collapse"},{"title":"Beauveria brongniartii - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beauveria_brongniartii"},{"title":"Alternative stable state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternative_stable_state"},{"title":"Evelyn Chrystalla Pielou - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._C._Pielou"},{"title":"Soil quality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil_quality"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about ecological stability:

## Definition and Core Concept

An ecosystem is said to possess ecological stability (or equilibrium) if it is capable of returning to its equilibrium state after a perturbation (a capacity known as resilience) or does not experience unexpected large changes in its characteristics across time.

## Historical Development and Terminology

The concept of ecological stability emerged in the first half of the 20th century, and with the advancement of theoretical ecology in the 1970s, the usage of the term has expanded to a wide variety of scenarios. However, this has created significant complexity. In 1997, Grimm and Wissel made an inventory of 167 definitions used in the literature and found 70 different stability concepts.(no content)One of the strategies that these two authors proposed to clarify the subject is to replace ecological stability with more specific terms, such as constancy, resilience and persistence.

## Types of Ecological Stability

Key categories include:

- **Dynamical Stability**: Dynamical stability refers to stability across time. A stable point is such that a small perturbation of the system will be diminished and the system will come back to the original point.

- **Resilience**: Resilience is the tendency of a system to retain its functional and organizational structure and the ability to recover after a perturbation or disturbance.

- **Resistance**: In the context of ecological stability, resistance is the property of communities or populations to remain "essentially unchanged" when subject to disturbance.

## Relationship Between Diversity and Stability

The relationship between diversity and stability has been widely studied. Diversity can enhance the stability of ecosystem functions at various ecological scales.

Links: [{"title":"Ecological stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_stability"},{"title":"Ecological effects of biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_effects_of_biodiversity"},{"title":"Resistance (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resistance_(ecology)"},{"title":"Carboniferous rainforest collapse - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carboniferous_rainforest_collapse"},{"title":"Beauveria brongniartii - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beauveria_brongniartii"},{"title":"Alternative stable state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternative_stable_state"},{"title":"Evelyn Chrystalla Pielou - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._C._Pielou"},{"title":"Soil quality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil_quality"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about ecological stability:

## Definition and Core Concept

An ecosystem is said to possess ecological stability (or equilibrium) if it is capable of returning to its equilibrium state after a perturbation (a capacity known as resilience) or does not experience unexpected large changes in its characteristics across time.

## Historical Development and Terminology

The concept of ecological stability emerged in the first half of the 20th century, and with the advancement of theoretical ecology in the 1970s, the usage of the term has expanded to a wide variety of scenarios. However, this has created significant complexity. In 1997, Grimm and Wissel made an inventory of 167 definitions used in the literature and found 70 different stability concepts.(no content)One of the strategies that these two authors proposed to clarify the subject is to replace ecological stability with more specific terms, such as constancy, resilience and persistence.

## Types of Ecological Stability

Key categories include:

- **Dynamical Stability**: Dynamical stability refers to stability across time. A stable point is such that a small perturbation of the system will be diminished and the system will come back to the original point.

- **Resilience**: Resilience is the tendency of a system to retain its functional and organizational structure and the ability to recover after a perturbation or disturbance.

- **Resistance**: In the context of ecological stability, resistance is the property of communities or populations to remain "essentially unchanged" when subject to disturbance.

## Relationship Between Diversity and Stability

The relationship between diversity and stability has been widely studied. Diversity can enhance the stability of ecosystem functions at various ecological scales.

Web search results for query: "microbial communities"

Links: [{"title":"Microbial consortium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_consortium"},{"title":"Seamount microbial communities - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seamount_microbial_communities"},{"title":"Hydrothermal vent microbial communities - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrothermal_vent_microbial_communities"},{"title":"Hadal zone microbial communities - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hadal_zone_microbial_communities"},{"title":"Sea ice microbial communities - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_ice_microbial_communities"},{"title":"Microbial population biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_population_biology"},{"title":"Synthetic microbial consortia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthetic_microbial_consortia"},{"title":"Microbiomes of the built environment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbiomes_of_the_built_environment"},{"title":"Microbiome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbiome"},{"title":"Exometabolomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exometabolomics"}]

I've performed a web search for "microbial communities" and found comprehensive information on the topic. Here's what the search revealed:

## Definition and Overview

A microbial community (also called a microbial consortium) is two or more bacterial or microbial groups living symbiotically. More broadly, a microbiome is the community of microorganisms that can usually be found living together in any given habitat.

## Key Characteristics

Environmental microbial communities show relatively high diversity levels, likely due to the high functional redundancy observed, which is a key asset of their functional stability.(no content)Consortia are more common than not in nature, and generally prove to be more robust than monocultures.

## Diverse Environments

Microbial communities exist in a wide variety of environments:

- **Marine environments**: The hydrothermal vent microbial community includes all unicellular organisms that live and reproduce in a chemically distinct area around hydrothermal vents, including organisms in the microbial mat, free floating cells, or bacteria in an endosymbiotic relationship with animals.

- **Polar regions**: Sea Ice Microbial Communities refer to groups of microorganisms living within and at the interfaces of sea ice at the poles, inhabiting an ice matrix with strong vertical gradients of salinity, light, temperature and nutrients.

- **Built environments**: Microbiomes of the built environment is a field of inquiry into the communities of microorganisms that live in human constructed environments like houses, cars and water pipes.

The search results cover various specialized microbial communities including those found in seamounts, deep ocean trenches, and synthetic laboratory-designed consortia for industrial applications.

Web search results for query: "biotic interactions"

Links: [{"title":"Biological interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_interaction"},{"title":"Extinction event - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extinction_event"},{"title":"Ecological fitting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_fitting"},{"title":"Biocoenosis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biocoenosis"},{"title":"Plant ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_ecology"},{"title":"Biotic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biotic"},{"title":"Biotic Ligand Model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biotic_Ligand_Model"},{"title":"Biotic stress - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biotic_stress"},{"title":"Ecosystem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem"},{"title":"Bioinformatics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bioinformatics"}]

Here's what I found about biotic interactions:

## Definition

In ecology, a biological interaction is the effect that a pair of organisms living together in a community have on each other.(no content)They can be either of the same species (intraspecific interactions), or of different species (interspecific interactions).

## Types of Biotic Interactions

Biological interactions range from mutualism, beneficial to both partners, to competition, harmful to both partners. Some key types include:

- **Competition**: Competition can be defined as an interaction between organisms or species, in which the fitness of one is lowered by the presence of another. Competition is often for a resource such as food, water, or territory in limited supply, or for access to females for reproduction.

- **Predation**: In predation, one organism, the predator, kills and eats another organism, its prey.

- **Mutualism**: Close and long-term interactions are described as symbiosis; symbioses that are mutually beneficial are called mutualistic.

## Nature of Interactions

Interactions can be direct when physical contact is established or indirect, through intermediaries such as shared resources, territories, ecological services, metabolic waste, toxins or growth inhibitors.(no content)These effects may be short-term, or long-term, both often strongly influence the adaptation and evolution of the species involved.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "functional group ecology"

Links: [{"title":"Functional group (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_group_(ecology)"},{"title":"Functional ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_ecology"},{"title":"Guild (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guild_(ecology)"},{"title":"Functional equivalence (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_equivalence_(ecology)"},{"title":"Plant functional type - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_functional_type"},{"title":"Diversity–function debate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diversity-function_debate"},{"title":"Functional group (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_group_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Ecosystem Functional Type - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_Functional_Type"},{"title":"Functional group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_group"},{"title":"Functional Ecology (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_Ecology_(journal)"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about functional group ecology:

## Definition

A functional group is a collection of organisms that share characteristics within a community.(no content)Ideally, these would perform equivalent tasks based on domain forces, rather than a common ancestor or evolutionary relationship.

## Types of Functional Groups

There are generally two types of functional groups that range between flora and specific animal populations. Groups that relate to vegetation science, or flora, are known as plant functional types (PFTs), which often share identical photosynthetic processes and require comparable nutrients.(no content)In contrast, those within the animal science range are called guilds typically sharing feeding types.

## Functional Traits

Modern ecologists favor a definition of traits often referred to as "functional traits", which are defined as morpho-physiophenological traits which impact fitness indirectly via their effects on growth, reproduction and survival.

## Importance for Ecosystem Health

Increased functional diversity increases both the capacity of the ecosystem to regulate the flux of energy and matter through the environment as well as the ecosystem's ability to produce resources beneficial to humans such as air, water, and wood.(no content)Reductions in functional diversity broadly impact the survivability of organisms in an environment regardless of functional group, trophic level, or species, implying that the organization and interaction of communities in an ecosystem has a profound impact on its ability to function and self-sustain.

## Functional Redundancy

In ecology, functional equivalence (or functional redundancy) is the ecological phenomenon that multiple species representing a variety of taxonomic groups can share similar, if not identical, roles in ecosystem functionality.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Functional group (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_group_(ecology)"},{"title":"Functional ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_ecology"},{"title":"Guild (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guild_(ecology)"},{"title":"Functional equivalence (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_equivalence_(ecology)"},{"title":"Plant functional type - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_functional_type"},{"title":"Diversity–function debate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diversity-function_debate"},{"title":"Functional group (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_group_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Ecosystem Functional Type - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_Functional_Type"},{"title":"Functional group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_group"},{"title":"Functional Ecology (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_Ecology_(journal)"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about functional group ecology:

## Definition

A functional group is a collection of organisms that share characteristics within a community.(no content)Ideally, these would perform equivalent tasks based on domain forces, rather than a common ancestor or evolutionary relationship.

## Types of Functional Groups

There are generally two types of functional groups that range between flora and specific animal populations. Groups that relate to vegetation science, or flora, are known as plant functional types (PFTs), which often share identical photosynthetic processes and require comparable nutrients.(no content)In contrast, those within the animal science range are called guilds typically sharing feeding types.

## Functional Traits

Modern ecologists favor a definition of traits often referred to as "functional traits", which are defined as morpho-physiophenological traits which impact fitness indirectly via their effects on growth, reproduction and survival.

## Importance for Ecosystem Health

Increased functional diversity increases both the capacity of the ecosystem to regulate the flux of energy and matter through the environment as well as the ecosystem's ability to produce resources beneficial to humans such as air, water, and wood.(no content)Reductions in functional diversity broadly impact the survivability of organisms in an environment regardless of functional group, trophic level, or species, implying that the organization and interaction of communities in an ecosystem has a profound impact on its ability to function and self-sustain.

## Functional Redundancy

In ecology, functional equivalence (or functional redundancy) is the ecological phenomenon that multiple species representing a variety of taxonomic groups can share similar, if not identical, roles in ecosystem functionality.

Links: [{"title":"Modularity (networks) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modularity_(networks)"},{"title":"Modularity (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modularity_(biology)"},{"title":"Louvain method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louvain_method"},{"title":"Modular neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_neural_network"},{"title":"Pollination network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pollination_network"},{"title":"Configuration model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Configuration_model"},{"title":"The Product Space - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Product_Space"},{"title":"Community structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_structure"},{"title":"White Rabbit Project - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_White_Rabbit_Project"},{"title":"Category:Modularity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Modularity"}]

I found comprehensive information about network modularity. Here's what the search revealed:

## Definition

Modularity is a measure of the structure of networks or graphs which measures the strength of division of a network into modules (also called groups, clusters or communities).(no content)Networks with high modularity have dense connections between the nodes within modules but sparse connections between modules.

## Key Characteristics

Modularity is a scale value between −1 (non-modular clustering) and 1 (fully modular clustering) that measures the relative density of edges inside communities with respect to edges outside communities.

## Practical Applications

Modularity is one such measure, which when maximized, leads to the appearance of communities in a given network. One prominent algorithmic approach is the Louvain method for community detection, a greedy optimization method intended to extract non-overlapping communities from large networks.

## Biological Context

In biology, modularity refers to the ability of a system to organize discrete, individual units that can overall increase the efficiency of network activity and, in a biological sense, facilitates selective forces upon the network.

## Important Limitations

Despite its widespread use, modularity optimization has notable drawbacks. Although the method of modularity maximization is motivated by computing a deviation from a null model, this deviation is not computed in a statistically consistent manner. Because of this, the method notoriously finds high-scoring communities in its own null model (the configuration model), which by definition cannot be statistically significant. Because of this, the method cannot be used to reliably obtain statistically significant community structure in empirical networks.

Based on the search results, here's information about oligotrophs and oligotrophic environments:

## Oligotroph Definition

An oligotroph is an organism that can live in an environment that offers very low levels of nutrients.(no content)They may be contrasted with copiotrophs, which prefer nutritionally rich environments.

## Characteristics

Oligotrophs are characterized by slow growth, low rates of metabolism, and generally low population density.(no content)Oligotrophs have acquired survival mechanisms that involve the expression of genes during periods of low nutrient conditions, which has allowed them to find success in various environments.

Interestingly, despite the capability to live in low nutrient concentrations, oligotrophs may find difficulty surviving in nutrient-rich environments, as the presence of excess nutrients overwhelm oligotroph's metabolic systems, which cause them to struggle to regulate nutrient uptake.

## Oligotrophic Environments

The term "oligotrophic" is commonly used to describe terrestrial and aquatic environments with very low concentrations of nitrates, iron, phosphates, and carbon sources.(no content)Oligotrophic lakes are most common in cold, sparsely developed regions that are underlain by crystalline igneous, granitic bedrock, and due to their low algal production, these lakes consequently have very clear waters, with high drinking-water quality.

Links: [{"title":"Stress gradient hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stress_gradient_hypothesis"},{"title":"Mark Bertness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Bertness"},{"title":"Red King hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_King_hypothesis"},{"title":"Hyperelastic material - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperelastic_material"},{"title":"Reynolds stress equation model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reynolds_stress_equation_model"},{"title":"Finite strain theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite_strain_theory"},{"title":"Goal pursuit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goal_pursuit"},{"title":"Objective stress rate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Objective_stress_rate"},{"title":"Stress majorization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stress_majorization"},{"title":"Alternative stress measures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biot_stress_tensor"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the Stress Gradient Hypothesis:

## Overview

The Stress Gradient Hypothesis (SGH) is an evolutionary theory in microbial ecology and community ecology that provides a framework to predict when positive or negative interactions should be observed in a habitat.

## Core Principle

The SGH states that facilitation, cooperation or mutualism should be more common in stressful environments, compared with benign environments (i.e nutrient excess) where competition or parasitism should be more common.

## Scientific Status

The stress gradient hypothesis, in which ecological interactions shift in a positive direction with increasing environmental stress, is controversial among ecologists, in part because of contradictory support. However, a 2021 meta analysis study compared SGH across different organisms with intraspecific and interspecific interactions and conclude that the SGH is indeed a broadly relevant ecological phenomena that is currently held back by cross-disciplinary communication barriers.

## Origin

The Stress Gradient Hypothesis was developed by Bertness and Callaway in 1994.

Links: [{"title":"Stress gradient hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stress_gradient_hypothesis"},{"title":"Mark Bertness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Bertness"},{"title":"Red King hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_King_hypothesis"},{"title":"Hyperelastic material - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperelastic_material"},{"title":"Reynolds stress equation model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reynolds_stress_equation_model"},{"title":"Finite strain theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite_strain_theory"},{"title":"Goal pursuit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goal_pursuit"},{"title":"Objective stress rate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Objective_stress_rate"},{"title":"Stress majorization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stress_majorization"},{"title":"Alternative stress measures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biot_stress_tensor"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the Stress Gradient Hypothesis:

## Overview

The Stress Gradient Hypothesis (SGH) is an evolutionary theory in microbial ecology and community ecology that provides a framework to predict when positive or negative interactions should be observed in a habitat.

## Core Principle

The SGH states that facilitation, cooperation or mutualism should be more common in stressful environments, compared with benign environments (i.e nutrient excess) where competition or parasitism should be more common.

## Scientific Status

The stress gradient hypothesis, in which ecological interactions shift in a positive direction with increasing environmental stress, is controversial among ecologists, in part because of contradictory support. However, a 2021 meta analysis study compared SGH across different organisms with intraspecific and interspecific interactions and conclude that the SGH is indeed a broadly relevant ecological phenomena that is currently held back by cross-disciplinary communication barriers.

## Origin

The Stress Gradient Hypothesis was developed by Bertness and Callaway in 1994.

Links: [{"title":"Biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity"},{"title":"Global biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_biodiversity"},{"title":"Biodiversity offsetting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_offsetting"},{"title":"Biodiversity hotspot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_hotspot"},{"title":"National Biodiversity Centre (Singapore) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Biodiversity_Centre_(Singapore)"},{"title":"List of biodiversity databases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_biodiversity_databases"},{"title":"Global Biodiversity Information Facility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Biodiversity_Information_Facility"},{"title":"Human Biodiversity Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Biodiversity_Institute"},{"title":"Food biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_biodiversity"},{"title":"Yamuna biodiversity park - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yamuna_biodiversity_park"}]

Here are the search results for "biodiversity":

## Definition and Measurement

Biodiversity is the variability of life on Earth.(no content)It can be measured on various levels, for example, genetic variability, species diversity, ecosystem diversity and phylogenetic diversity.

## Global Biodiversity Overview

Estimates on the number of Earth's current species range from 2 million to 1 trillion, but most estimates are around 11 million species or fewer.(no content)Diversity is not distributed evenly on Earth—it is greater in the tropics as a result of the warm climate.

## Biodiversity Loss

The current state of biodiversity is concerning. The planet has lost 58% of its biodiversity since 1970 according to a 2016 study by the World Wildlife Fund.(no content)All contemporary biodiversity loss has been attributed to human activities.

Major drivers of biodiversity loss include:
- Destroying habitats for farming is a key reason why biodiversity is decreasing today.
- Climate change also plays a role.

## Biodiversity Hotspots

A biodiversity hotspot is a biogeographic region with significant levels of biodiversity that is threatened by human habitation.(no content)Globally, 36 zones qualify under this definition. These sites support nearly 60% of the world's plant, bird, mammal, reptile, and amphibian species.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "network cohesion"

Links: [{"title":"Structural cohesion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_cohesion"},{"title":"Group cohesiveness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_cohesiveness"},{"title":"Collective network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_network"},{"title":"Cohesion (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cohesion_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Cohesion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cohesion"},{"title":"Silhouette (clustering) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silhouette_(clustering)"},{"title":"Garance Genicot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garance_Genicot"},{"title":"Joseph Galaskiewicz - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Galaskiewicz"},{"title":"European Observation Network for Territorial Development and Cohesion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Observation_Network_for_Territorial_Development_and_Cohesion"}]

I've performed a web search on "network cohesion." Here are the key findings:

## Main Concepts of Network Cohesion

**In Social Networks:**
Cohesion refers to the degree to which actors are connected directly to each other by cohesive bonds, with structural cohesion referring to the minimum number of members who, if removed from a group, would disconnect the group.(no content)Group cohesion is the degree or strength of bonds linking members of a social group to one another and to the group as a whole.(no content)These bonds develop from components such as attraction, coordination, sense ofbelonging and shared emotions.

**Formal Definition:**
In sociology, structural cohesion is a formal definition and measure of cohesion in social groups, defined as the minimal number of actors in a social network that need to be removed to disconnect the group.

**In Data Science:**
In clustering and machine learning contexts, the silhouette value is a measure of how similar an object is to its own cluster (cohesion) compared to other clusters (separation).

**Related Concepts:**
Groups are identified as 'cliques' if every individual is directly tied to every other individual, 'social circles' if there is less stringency of direct contact, or as structurally cohesive blocks if precision is wanted.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the knowledge graph extraction task. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** contribution

**Key Findings:**
- Extracted 14 triples from the paper's title and abstract
- All entities identified are conceptual frameworks used or proposed by the paper
- The paper **proposes** using the negative:positive cohesion ratio as a novel network metric to predict microbial community stability under environmental stress
- The paper **uses** existing concepts like network theory, modularity, ecological stability, microbiome science, and the stress gradient hypothesis

**Triples Created:**
1. Microbiome (uses)
2. Network theory (uses)
3. Modularity (networks) (uses)
4. Ecological stability (uses)
5. Soil microbiology (uses)
6. Ecosystem services (uses)
7. Biodiversity (uses)
8. Functional group (ecology) (uses)
9. Biological interaction (uses)
10. Mutualism (biology) (uses)
11. Pathogen (uses)
12. Oligotroph (uses)
13. Stress gradient hypothesis (uses)
14. Structural cohesion (proposes)

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED - All requirements met with 1 "proposes" relation and 13 "uses" relations, totaling 14 concept entities.

Sources:
- [Microbiome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbiome)
